Award.AwardTitle: Graduate Student Support for the 2013 Gene Golub SIAM Summer School in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for US-based Ph.D. student participation in the Gene Golub SIAM Summer School, which will coincide with the International Summer School on Numerical Linear Algebra (ISSNLA) on July 22 - August 2, 2013 at Fudan University in Shanghai, China. The conference encourages and financially supports participation by members of groups underrepresented in mathematics.

The meeting includes invited lectures on topics of current research interest in computatonal mathematics. The conference brings together workers in a variety of different areas of research in numerical linear algebra, with emphasis on preparing Ph.D. students for useful and engaging research careers. Allocation of the funds will be based on scientific merit, financial need, and diversity, with an emphasis on participation by members of underrepresented groups.

Conference web site: http://g2s3.cs.ucdavis.edu

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant awarded graduate students from US institutions to attend the 2013 Gene Golub SIAM Summer School held in Fudan University, Shanghai, China.  The summer school offered three courses on recent developments in numerical linear algebra and on novel applications to other disciplines. These courses covered underlying theory and a variety of algorithms for
matrix functions and matrix equations that are widely used in applications, such as exponential integrators for the solution of partial differential equations and model reduction of large scale dynamical systems. They also covered high performance linear solvers and eigenvalue and singular value computations, which are relevant to matrix functions and matrix equations.These are forward-looking courses which cover topics that are too recent to have been included in textbooks or doctoral courses.
 The lecturers are leading experts who are also well known for their
expository skills. 12 US students are selected thoughly a highly
competitive process among a large pool of international applicants.
These students are working in broader field that requires results and methods from numerical linear algebra.  An ancillary outcome is the contacts
that the participants acquire during the summer school, which will lead
to future collaborations. This NSF grant had a significant impact on
the continued strong competitiveness of the US in this crucial discipline
with its connections to virtually every scientific computing problem area.

Course materials, including video of lectures,  are made available to
the public at the SIAM site
http://www.siam.org/students/g2s3/2013/index.html
